definitions.definition: to affect or make something affect, be known by, or be used by more and more people

examples.text: The news had spread and was causing great excitement.
Use of computers **spread rapidly** during that period.
Within weeks, his confidence had spread throughout the team.
The disease spreads easily.
The idea **spread quickly** in the years that followed.
Someone's been **spreading rumours** about you.
He's using his rap music to **spread the message** that violence is wrong.
The **disease is spread** by mosquitoes.
The virus is primarily spread from person to person through coughing and sneezing.
The depression started in the US and spread quickly throughout the world.
His fame had spread far and wide.
The disease can be spread by contact.
I wish he would stop spreading lies about me.
The effects of this policy spread far beyond children now at school.

definitions.definition: to cover, or to make something cover, a larger and larger area

examples.text: There is no evidence that the cancer has spread.
The fire rapidly spread to adjoining buildings.
Water began to spread across the floor.
A smile spread slowly across her face.
Allow plenty of space for this plant as its roots spread widely.
A strong wind spread the flames.
Using too much water could spread the stain.

definitions.definition: to cause somebody/something to be in a number of different places

examples.text: Seeds and pollen are spread by the wind.
We have 10â€‰000 members spread all over the country.
Expertise in this field is very thinly spread across the country.
Friends may be spread geographically. Neighbours, by definition, are nearby.
The valley spread out beneath us.

definitions.definition: to put a layer of a substance onto the surface of something; to be able to be put onto a surface
definitions.sensetop: spread somethingspread (A on/over B)spread (B with A)

examples.text: They spread manure in both spring and autumn.
to spread butter on pieces of toast
Birds spread the oil over their feathers to keep them warm and dry.
pieces of toast spread with butter
If the paint is too thick, it will not spread evenly.
He spread jam on the toast.
Spread each slice generously with butter.
If the paint is too thick, it will not spread easily.
She spread butter on a piece of toast.
Spread the cake with cream and then sprinkle flakes of chocolate on top.

definitions.definition: to open something that has been folded so that it covers a larger area than before
definitions.sensetop: spread something (out)spread something (out) on/over somethingspread something + adj.

examples.text: The bird spread its wings.
a bird with its wings spread wide
They spread a cloth on the table.
Sue spread the map out on the floor.
We spread the rug out on the floor.
He spread the blanket over the straw and went to sleep.
He had a newspaper spread open on his knee.

phrases: spread your arms, legs, etc. out wide
spread your arms, legs, etc. wide

definitions.definition: to arrange objects so that they cover a large area and can be seen easily
definitions.sensetop: spread something out on/over somethingspread something out

examples.text: Papers had been spread out on the desk.
She spread out photographs of her grandchildren so I could see how they'd grown.
He was studying the various pages of notes spread over the quilt.
He shuffled the cards and spread them in a fan.

phrases: spread your arms, legs, etc. out wide
spread your arms, legs, etc. wide

definitions.definition: to place the thumb and a finger of one hand on the screen of an electronic device such as a mobile phone or small computer and move them apart to make the image on the screen larger, as though it is closer

examples.text: Re-size the text by using the pinch and spread gestures on the screen.

definitions.definition: to move your arms, legs, fingers, etc. far apart from each other

examples.text: She spread her arms and the child ran towards her.

phrases: spread your arms, legs, etc. out wide
spread your arms, legs, etc. wide

definitions.definition: to separate something into parts and divide them between different times or different people
definitions.sensetop: spread somethingspread something (out) (over something)spread something between somebody/something

examples.text: Why not pay monthly and spread the cost of your car insurance?
A series of five interviews will be spread over two days.
The course takes forty hours, spread over twenty weeks.
We attempted to spread the workload between the departments.
We tried to spread the workload evenly between the departments.

definitions.definition: to become known by more and more people very quickly

examples.text: Rumours of his death spread like wildfire.
The news spread like wildfire.

definitions.definition: to consider a wide range of possibilities or cover a large area, especially to try to find somebody/something

examples.text: They have spread their net far and wide in the search for a new team coach.

definitions.definition: to become more independent and confident and try new activities, etc.

examples.text: Going to college gave her the chance to spread her wings.
I'm always trying to spread the word about healthy eating.

definitions.definition: to try to do so many different things at the same time that you do not do any of them well

examples.text: With four markets to manage, there's a danger that's she's spreading herself too thin.
